title: How to determine whether “and” connects words or parts of sentences - Quora

response.answer_text: OK. Here is the sentence and the related question under consideration (what I see when I click on the link): The sight of the little Breton peasant who did her humble housework aroused in her despairing regrets and ________ dreams.(distract) Distracted or Distracting? Which one should I choose? I think the problem is I don’t know whether the “and” connects (a) verb + verb or (b) noun + noun. “Distracted dreams” is a phrase that uses a certain type of netaphor, one that nominally turns something non-living into a living being. Specifically, here, the word “dreams” becomes a person, and even more specifically, a distracted person. We see a similar type of use of metaphor in the common phrase “until Death do us part” where Death is seen as a person, not as a process, and thus parts the husband from the wife, by more or less stepping between them. Even if this were not the case, clearly, in this particular sentence, “distracting” is the correct choice because of the rule of parallelism. Given that the first part says “despairing regrets”, the second part must say, “distracting thoughts” so that both, “despair” and “despair” end in -ing. The overall tone and style of this sentence (the one in bold) is awful and disgusting, though, and I can’t imagine that anyone sensible would talk or write in this way, unless he or she were completely drunk while slowly going insane, on a particularly bad day for both (getting drunk and going insane). Anyway, to determine what, exactly, and (or any other conjunction) connects to what, you need to read that specific sentence, very carefully. There is no rule or formula. For example, the and in “salt and pepper” is a different kind of and than the one in “salt and oil.” The salt and pepper thing is a complete phrase. Salt and pepper kind of go together. They’re an item, a couple, a married couple, really, not boyfriend and girlfriend. Salt and oil are just total strangers. They’re just completely random people thrown together by circumstances. On the other hand, “bread and salt”, both being basic necessities, go together but like boyfriend and girlfriend. They date when they want to and generally like each other but could also easily live without each other. They’re much more than just friends. They may or not be lovers. They’re certainly not a genuine couple. In each of these cases, the word and is just connecting together individual words. But each use is a very specialised use. You really need to read the specifics of the situation (the entire sentence as well as the overall context within which you are reading that sentence), to gauge proper usage.
